| - 1. **Ethics and Human Interface**                                                                         | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Ethics is set of moral principles that helps in identifying right and wrong behaviour<br>        - "Ethics is knowing the difference between what you have a right to do and what is right to do." -Potter Stewart<br><br>- - Ethics<br>        - Externally imposed (morals internally)<br>        - Tend to be consistent and objective (moral - subjectivity)<br><br>- - Teleology<br>        - Ethical doctrine which asserts that every entity have an inherent purpose or end (telos) towards which they strive<br><br>- - "The good of an individual is contained in the good of all"<br>        - The statement suggests that individual wellbeing is deeply connected with wellbeing of society as a whole.<br>        - Interconnectedness : decision of individual have ripple effect on society.<br>            - E.g. Gandhi's promotion of Khadi<br>        - Mutual dependence : we rely on other for resources, support and sense of belonging<br><br>- - Human beings should always be treated as ‘ends’ in themselves and never as merely `means’<br>        - The statement is rooted in deontological ethics of Immanuel Kant.<br>        - End in themselves : Humans possess inherent worth and dignity based on their own existence, not on their utility.<br>            - Intrinsic Worth<br>                - Ensuring fair wages and humane working conditions for all<br>            - Respect for Autonomy<br>                - Informed consent in data sharing<br>            - Human Dignity<br>                - Abolition of untouchability<br>            - Ethical Relationship : based on mutual respect, not selfish gain<br>            - Foundation of Human Rights<br>            - Against Utilitarianism<br>                - Business should focus on ESG rather solely on profit<br>        - Means to an end : reduced human value as a tool to achieve goal - disregarding their value.<br>            - E.g. slavery<br>        - Significance<br>            - Safeguarding life and personal liberty<br>            - Social justice<br><br>- - The crisis of ethical values in modern times is traced to a narrow perception of the good life.<br>        - The crisis of ethical values in modern times means erosion of values due to impact of urbanization, globalization, economic development and technology.<br>        - Arguments<br>            - Individualism : "every man for himself" mentality : overshadowing ethics and compassion<br>                - E.g. breaking up of JF<br>            - Materialism and Consumerism<br>                - E.g. McDonalisation of food habits<br>            - Instant Gratification and Hedonism<br>                - Binge watching of web series<br>            - Narrow markers of success : wealth, fame, beauty<br>                - Fast fashion, social media envy<br>            - Competition<br>                - Reduce trust in interpersonal relations<br>            - Technology : reduced us to narrow virtual existence detached from real world experiences.<br>                - 1000 friends on Facebook, none in real life<br>            - God is dead<br>        - Counter arguments<br>            - Depends on individual<br>                - Warren Buffet - 99% wealth to philanthropy<br>                - Tribals worship nature - sacred grooves<br>            - Positives of modernity : liberty, innovation, creativity, independent decision-making<br>        - Moving beyond narrow perception<br>            - Value education<br>            - Broadening conception of good life<br><br>- - **Significance**<br>        - Individual<br>            - Integrity : to resolve ethical dilemmas, resist temptations of wrongdoing<br>            - Compassion towards weaker sections<br>        - Society<br>            - Promotes Justice and Equality<br>        - Organizations<br>            - Builds Trust and Cooperation<br>        - Environment<br>            - Ensures Sustainability : by non-exploitative use of natural resources<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4.png>)<br>    - **Challenges \| consequences of unethical behaviour**<br>        - Individual<br>            - Loss of self-respect : can lead to guilt, shame, and a diminished sense of self-worth.<br>            - Mental and emotional harm : can cause stress, anxiety, and even depression.<br>            - Limited personal growth : reduce opportunities for learning, moral development and forming genuine connections.<br>        - Social<br>            - Increased conflict and distrust : hate speech, communalism, racism, intolerance<br>            - Social and economic problems : poverty, discrimination, inequality, exploitation<br>        - Governance<br>            - Weakened governance : leads to corruption, misuse of power.<br>        - Environmental<br>            - Overexploitation of resources, pollution, and ecological degradation<br>        - Unethical use of technology : purposes such as mass surveillance, privacy violations threatening democracy<br><br>- - **How ethics can be developed?**<br>        - Internal development<br>            - Critical thinking : analyze situations objectively, identify potential biases, and consider various perspectives.<br>            - Defining core values and principles : What matters most to you? What do you believe in? What is your philosophy of life?<br>            - Moral reasoning : Learn about different ethical frameworks and theories, such as utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics.<br>            - Develop self-awareness : being honest, recognizing personal bias, and acting with integrity<br>        - External Engagement<br>            - Education : Read books on ethics, philosophy, and social justice.<br>            - Role models : learning from individuals who embody the ethical values you aspire to.<br>            - Social accountability : speaking up against injustice, wrongdoing, challenging status quo and advocating reforms.<br><br>- - **What are different theories of ethics?**<br>        - _Consequentialist approach - morality of action is judged solely by it's consequences._<br>            - State consequentialism : raison d'état [Machiavelli]<br>                - Hans Morganthau - ethics apply to individuals not states<br>            - Society consequentialism : Socialism [Karl Marx]<br>                - _“Falsehood takes the place of truth when it results in unblemished common good.”- Tirukkural_<br><br>Lies for Social Harmony<br><br>E.g. withholding information to prevent chaos<br><br>Emergency Situations:<br><br>E.g. espionage involve deception to protect national interest<br><br>Avoiding Harm:<br><br>E.g. Doctor lying about terminally ill patient for hope and improvement<br><br>Conflict Resolution:<br><br>Concealing truth to reach peace<br><br>Protection of Vulnerable Groups<br><br>- - - - Utilitarian<br>                - Quantitative<br><br>Believes that all pleasures are alike<br><br>The greatest happiness of the greatest number is the foundation of morals and legislation. - Jeremy Bentham<br><br>[Carvaka.(चार्वाक)](onenote:#Art%20and%20Culture&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={EA0BB9C4-4F0E-4348-BD99-E70ED41A76A5}&object-id={F826FBCA-C195-7548-BB10-9F9D5C584997}&8B&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br><br>- - - - - Qualitative<br><br>All pleasures are not equal.<br><br>Intellectual pleasures better then sensory pleasures<br><br>It is better to be a man dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied” -Mill<br><br>Advantages<br><br>- - Pragmatic solutions<br>        - Progressive taxation for social welfare program<br>        - Whistleblowing to protect public interest - Edward Snowden<br>    - Greater good<br>        - Torturing terrorist to know the location of planted bombs<br>    - Utilitarian approach<br>        - Covid 19 Lockdown : restricting freedom to protect public health<br>    - Emergency Situation : life/death - strict adherence to ethics not possible<br>        - E.g. war or national security<br>        - E.g. Bangladesh Liberation War for protecting human rights<br>    - Violent Revolution against oppressive regime<br>        - E.g. Student Protest - Bangladesh<br>        - 'do or die' [Gandhi] during QIM 1942<br>    - [“Falsehood takes the place of truth when it results in](onenote:#GS4&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={44232157-14DC-244B-9A67-E7D81ED82C04}&object-id={1BF7E243-276A-AC44-B0D9-2FBD8F4186C2}&44&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br><br>- - _Deontological approach - morality is judged by duty or action and not the consequences._<br><br>Some actions are right and wrong in themselves, irrespective of consequences<br><br>- - Immanuel Kant - Categorical moral reasoning<br>        - Asserts that there are certain inviolable moral laws.<br>        - _An action, to have moral worth, must be done from duty._<br>        - **Categorical imperative** - Act according to that maxim whereby it should become a universal moral law.<br>            - It means ask yourself if you would be comfortable if everyone acted in the way you are considering<br>    - Gandhi<br>        - Truth and non-violence<br>        - Emphasis on practical idealism<br>        - Action is moral if its intentional, universal, practical, selfless, free from fear<br>        - Gandhi's Talisman<br>        - 7 deadly sins<br>        - Nai Talim<br><br>- - Buddha<br>    - Confucius<br>        - Golden rule - we shall do to others what we want others to do to us.<br>    - निष्काम कर्म - Devotion to duty is the highest form of worship<br>    - **Why to prefer this over consequentialism?**<br>        - Violation of ethical integrity<br>        - Erosion of trust<br>        - Ends can't be known - potential for harm<br>            - E.g. Russia's invasion of Ukraine for quick victory<br>        - Slippery slope - erosion of ethical standards<br>            - E.g. Bulldozer justice erodes rule of law<br>        - Long term harm - what you sow is what you reap<br>            - E.g. clearing rainforest for palm cultivation - climate change<br>            - Harbouring anti-India terrorism in Pakistan<br>        - Wrong precedence<br>            - Surveillance for safety raise concern about privacy and abuse of power<br>        - Protecting universal moral principles<br>            - E.g. manual scavenging is wrong<br>    - Advantages of deontology?<br>        - Long term good<br>            - E.g. independence by non violent means<br>    - Disadvantages of deontology<br>        - Against contextual ethics : suboptimal outcome<br>            - Ethical to harm someone in self protection<br>        - Larger social good compromised<br>            - E.g. IPR protection for vaccine - limits benefits to poor<br>            - Land reforms<br>        - Rigidity - difficulty in adapting to change<br>            - E.g. total regulation of AI may prevent it's development<br>        - Universalist and determinist : against moral relativism<br><br>- - _Virtue Ethics - behavior showing high moral standards_<br>        - Emphasizes the role of individual character in moral decision-making<br>        - **Virtues** are golden mean between two extreme vices<br>            - Courage between rashness and cowardice<br>            - Self control between indulgence and excessive repression<br>            - Good life - right combination of hedonism and eudemonism<br>                - Hedonism - pursuit of pleasure<br>                - Eudemonism - pursuit of happiness<br>        - **Virtues** as per Plato - **wisdom**, **courage, temperance, justice.**<br>        - A virtuous person always does the right thing - Plato<br>        - A good life is life of virtues - Plato<br>        - Aristotle<br>        - Genius can take you to heights, but character will decide whether you stays there. **- Albert Einstein**<br><br>- - _Contextual ethics_<br>        - _Right and wrong depend upon the situation. There are no universal moral rules or rights._<br>            - _E.g. Article 358 suspends freedom of speech during national emergency_<br>        - _Concerns_<br>            - Slippery slope<br>                - Harmless decision now may lead to much worse outcome in long term<br><br>E.g. appeasement of Hitler became cause for World War 2<br><br>- - _Ethics of merit-  Treating persons based on merit as a exercise of justice_<br>        - Rewards based on merit<br>        - Supporters - Robert Nozick<br>        - Entitlement theory<br>            - Ex. Rewarding hard work and excellence<br><br>- - _Ethical voluntarism - fair due to consent of the individual._<br>        - Moral obligations arise from voluntary acts of the will.<br>            - E.g. plea bargain for lenient sentence<br>    - _The Ethics of 'Growing the Pie' - focus on expanding total resource instead of redistribution_<br>        - E.g. Green Revolution over poor land reforms<br>    - Ethical egoism - according to this theory, moral decision should be guided entirely by self interest.<br>        - E.g. lying to win in election<br>    - **Conclusion**<br>        - Adherence to ethics is the cornerstone for more compassionate, just and sustainable world.<br>        - Treating humans as end in themselves is foundation of just society.<br>        - As Plato said, 'Ethics is nothing else than reverence for good life.'<br><br>- - In conclusion, we can heed to words of Aristotle, he said that neither the principles nor the consequence but a reasoned combination of both makes a good moral judgement. | Essence                                                                                                     | - - The essence of ethics is about understanding the core principles and qualities that underpins ethical behaviour and decision-making.<br>    - It goes beyond simple set of rules or commands and answers fundamental questions like why and how of living a good and meaningful life.<br><br>- - Key aspects of the essence of ethics<br>        - Universal values : At its core, ethics revolves around universal values like justice, fairness, honesty, respect, compassion, and responsibility.<br>        - Internal reflection : accessing our core values, learning from mistakes and adopting to broader social changes.<br>        - Intention : having right intentions that aligns ones action and values.<br>        - Critical thinking : questioning dogma and social norms. Challenging status quo and unjust practices.<br>        - Social impact : ethical decisions have ripple effects on individuals, communities and society at large. | Determinants of Ethics Human Action                                                                         | - - Internal determinants.<br>        - Conscience - inner voice that tells of moral correctness of specific conduct.<br>        - Intuition - the ability to understand something immediately, without the need for conscious reasoning.<br>        - Values: represent what we consider important and worth striving for in life.<br>            - Personal Values<br>                - Honesty, compassion, perseverance, empathy, tolerance<br>            - Cultural Values<br>                - Social norms, religious customs<br>                - Socialism, secularism, democracy, republicanism<br>            - Historical values<br>                - Caste system not valid today<br>            - Change due to socio-economic and technological progress<br>            - Universal Values<br>                - Human Rights, freedom, equality, peace, justice<br>        - Beliefs : are our conviction of something which we consider to be true<br>            - They are our understanding of truth, scientific theories, religious doctrines.<br>            - They can be clouded by<br>                - Personal bias<br>                - Social and religious norms and dogmas<br>                - Ethnic or national interest<br>            - Correcting wrong beliefs?<br>                - Self reflection : staying open to the possibility of being wrong<br>                - Critical thinking: objective analysis, reasoned arguments and considering alternate perspective<br>                - Openness to learning : exploring diverse viewpoints<br>                - Humility : staying humble and being willing to change ones mind.<br>        - Moral compass:<br>            - Morals are beliefs of individual or group about right and wrong behaviour<br>                - E.g. respect for elderlies<br>            - Amoral - indifferent about morality<br>            - Immoral - doing evil acts<br>            - Morality refers to set of principles that guide individual decisions about right and wrong.<br>            - Ethics are collective proposition of society. Moral are individual propositions.<br>            - Moral Subjectivity : moral judgments and values are based on individual perspectives, feelings, or opinions.<br>                - Just because majority believes in something does not makes it moral. Ex. Dowry, Sati<br>            - Moral Relativism - no single set of moral principles can account for all the situations.<br>                - Context and circumstances matters : morals may change due to societal evolution and technological development<br><br>E.g. homosexuality earlier considered immoral, now changing perception<br><br>E.g. slavery not immoral in America before Civil war.<br><br>- - - - - One can be good without conformity to rules of society. Ex. Raja Ram Mohan Roy<br>            - What is right?<br>                - Right refers to things that a particular group approves of.<br>            - Moral absolutism - belief that there are such moral rules that apply to everyone. Takes universal view of humanity<br>                - E.g. Deontological ethics of Kant<br>                - E.g. Universal Declaration of Human Rights<br>                - E.g. | Consequences of Ethics in Human Action                                                                      | - - Consequences of ethics mean the outcome of human actions which are guided by ethical thinking. This means consequences also determine how good or bad an act is.<br><br>- - For **Individual**<br>        - Self respect<br>        - Good health Well-Being<br>        - Stronger relationships<br>        - Access to opportunities<br>        - Moral Guidance : to choose the right course of action<br>            - E.g. Don't cheat in exam instead pursue academic success by working hard<br>        - Objective decision making<br>            - E.g. report a colleague's unethical behavior<br>        - Peaceful Conflict resolution : prioritizing dialogue<br>            - E.g. On disagreement with my brother<br><br>- - For **Society**<br>        - Ripple effect : creates a more just and equitable society<br>        - Social cohesion : sense of unity and belonging<br>    - For environment<br>    - For governance<br>    - Global impact<br>        - Interconnected world : ethics transcending borders<br><br>- - **For Organization**<br>        - Sustainability<br>            - E.g. Railways aim to become carbon neutral by 2030<br>        - Conducive Work culture<br>            - E.g. employee will honestly point out the lapses -> continuous improvement<br>        - Retain and attract talent<br>        - Develop leaders<br>            - E.g. Ratan Tata<br>        - Managing conflict of interest<br><br>- - E.g. justice UU Lalit recused himself<br>    - E.g. Rakesh Maria's efforts for police reforms in Mumbai<br><br>- - In resolving conflict<br>        - Provide guiding principles for decision making<br>        - Effective communication - open and honest dialogue<br>            - E.g. | ### Dimensions of Ethics                                                                                    | - - Dimensions of ethics refers to different frameworks to categorize ethics.<br><br>- - Meta-Ethics : is concerned with the philosophical foundations of ethics.<br>        1. "What is the nature of moral truth?<br>        2. "How do we know what is morally right or wrong?<br>    - Normative Ethics: focuses on prescribing what we ought to do and what is good, right, or ethical.<br>        1. What actions are morally right or wrong? What principles should guide ethical decision-making?<br>    - Descriptive Ethics: investigates what ethical beliefs are held by different individuals and groups, and how they act ethically.<br>    - Applied Ethics : explores how ethical principles can be applied to specific real-world problems and situations in different fields<br>        1. Accountability<br>                - E.g. public apology for corporate mistakes<br>        - Limitations<br>            - Morals are subjective : prioritizing personal ethics over law can undermine the legal system<br>            - Contextual dependency : public servants must prioritize laws<br>            - adhering to laws is cornerstone to well functioning society<br><br>- - Judge your success by what you had to give up in order to get it.” Dalai Lama.<br>        - Meaning of success :<br>            - External : wealth, fame, power<br>            - Internal : happiness, contentment, love, compassion<br>        - Need for sacrifice<br>            - For external success<br>                - may require giving time, comfort, peace of mind<br>            - For internal success<br>                - Give up our greed, anger, intolerance<br>                - Overcome our own biases and prejudices<br>        - Challenges in application<br>            - Setting priority : requires giving up certain things<br>            - Subjectivity : journey of success is not smooth<br>            - Uncertainty of outcomes |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |

| - 1. **Emotional Intelligence**<br><br>Concept \| Utilities                                                 | - - **Introduction**<br>        - _“As much as 80% of adult success comes from EQ” - Daniel Goleman_<br>        - EI is the ability recognize emotions and use them for constructive purpose.<br><br>- - Intelligence is defined as the capacity of an individual to think rationally, act purposefully and deal effectively with his environment.<br>        - **TR-AP-DE**<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 6.png>)<br>    - I know that I am intelligent, because I know that I know nothing -Socrates<br>    - It takes more then intelligence to act intelligently - Dostoevsky<br>    - Emotional intelligence - Sthithapragya - steady wisdom<br><br>- - **Emotions**<br>        - Intense feelings, favourable/unfavourable, directed at someone/something.<br>        - Happy - feeling of contentment<br><br>- - **Quote**<br>        - You are punished not for your **anger** but by your anger. - Buddha<br><br>- - Anger : is a strong feeling of annoyance or resentment against someone/something<br>        - Cloud judgement of right or wrong<br>            - Naked parade of women in Manipur<br>        - Escalate conflict<br>            - Israel's response to October 7 Hamas Attack<br>        - Prohibits rational thinking<br>            - Peoples attacking doctors<br>        - Overpowers other emotions<br>            - Naxalism, Terrorism - suicide bombing<br>        - Affects peace of mind<br>            - Uneasiness, restlessness<br>        - Affect interpersonal relationships<br>            - Creates mistrust, conflict<br>        - Prevents objective assessment<br>            - By Clouding judgement<br>        - Nasty decision making<br>            - General Dyer<br><br>- - **Management of anger**<br>        - Identifying triggers<br>        - Noticing early signs - self awareness<br>        - Mindfulness meditation<br>        - Channelling<br>            - Peace and Reconciliation Commission - South Africa<br>        - Practice forgiveness<br>            - Bus diplomacy of Vajpayee<br>        - Seek external support<br><br>- - **Body**<br>        - Peter Salovey and John Mayor - **defined** the term EI - **PUMU**<br>            - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 7.png>)<br>        - Denial Goleman - 5 components of emotional intelligence<br><br>![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 13.jpeg>)<br><br>**ARM(E)S**<br><br>- - Self awareness - _Ability to recognize and understand emotions as well as their effect on others_<br>        - E.g. while having quarrel with my brother<br>    - Self Regulation - _Ability to control disruptive impulses, tendency to suspend judgment and to think before acting._<br>    - Motivation - _Passion to work for internal reasons that go beyond external rewards like money and status._<br>        - E.g. joy of learning<br>    - Empathy - _Putting oneself in someone else's shoes and understanding their feelings and experiences_.<br>    - Social Skills - _Proficiency in managing relationships and building networks, and the ability to find common ground and to build rapport._<br>        - _Leading change, persuasiveness, expertise building_<br>    - _![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 8.png>)_<br>    - Adaptability : adjust to changing need<br>    - Resilience : bouncing back from setbacks<br>    - Optimism : maintaining a positive outlook<br><br>- - **Qualities of emotionally intelligent people**<br>        - Good interpersonal relations<br>        - Improved communication<br>        - Empathy<br>        - Learning from mistakes<br>        - Acting with integrity<br>        - Reduced stress<br>        - Feeling confident and positive<br>        - Creativity<br><br>- - **Utilities of emotional intelligence**<br>        - Personal benefit<br>            - Enhanced self awareness<br>                - manage stress effectively, better decision making<br>                - keep even temper in managing success and failure<br>            - High adversity quotient<br>                - overcome obstacles to achieve happiness<br>            - Physical and mental Health<br>                - Overcoming anxiety, depression, trauma, loss of dear ones<br>            - Reduced Emotional Bias<br>                - Think rationally<br>            - Effective communication<br>                - Allows to express and articulate thoughts clearly<br>            - Conflict resolution<br>                - By facilitating constructive dialogue<br>                - E.g. RN Ravi in Naga peace accord<br>            - Interpersonal Relationship<br>                - builds trust and fosters deeper connections with others<br>        - Professional Benefits<br>            - Leadership<br>                - Create positive work environment<br>            - Improved career prospects<br>                - Helps to build rapport with colleagues and clients<br>            - Enhance job performance and productivity<br>                - By effective communication, team spirit<br><br>- - **How Emotional Intelligence can be developed?**<br>        - Self awareness : identification of root of distress and addressing it.<br>            - Self reflection<br>            - Practicing mindfulness, journaling<br>        - Social awareness<br>            - Anticipating and recognising needs and situations<br>        - Self-Regulation - responding calmly and optimistically<br>            - Choosing a thoughtful response<br>        - Motivation<br>            - Establish clear, achievable goals<br>        - Seeking Feedback - taking constructive criticism from family, colleague, psychologist<br>            - Course correction, self-improvement<br>        - Practicing Empathy<br>            - E.g. Actively Listening to others<br>        - Invest time and effort in building relationship<br>        - Undertaking sensitivity training or self introspection<br>            - E.g., sensitization towards LGBTQIA+ community.<br>        - Soft skill training<br>            - According to 2nd ARC<br>        - Friendly work culture<br>            - Gives positivity<br>        - Self expression<br>            - Relief in case of ethical conflict; seeking help<br>        - Having rich emotional vocabulary<br><br>- - **Negative effects of having high EI?**<br>        - Emotional overload, burnout : due to constant exposure to others intense emotions<br>        - Emotional manipulation of other for personal benefit<br>            - E.g. Hitler used emotion to suppress reason of Germans<br>        - Ignoring emotional signals can be counterproductive<br>            - They act as warning signals<br>        - Unhealthy people-pleasing tendencies<br>            - Might lead to compromising their own need and boundaries<br>        - Misinterpretations and over-analysis of others' intentions<br>            - Create conflict and miscommunication<br><br>- - **Limitations of emotional intelligence in resolving COC**<br><br>[”A system of morality which is based on relative emotional](onenote:#GS4&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={44232157-14DC-244B-9A67-E7D81ED82C04}&object-id={42A97C41-5646-5E45-B260-51F6BF968B6B}&F&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br><br>- - Emotional bias : emotion can still cloud the judgement<br>    - External pressure : may overpower strong emotions or principles<br>        - E.g. suicide bombing<br>    - Ethical ambiguity : when there is no right or wrong answer<br>    - Individual variability<br>        - Some can overemphasize empathy for certain stakeholders<br>    - Situational constraints like limited time or resources limit EI<br><br>- - **What prevents development of EI?**<br>        - Early Life Factors:<br>            - Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) like trauma, neglect, abuse, or chaotic family environments<br>        - Lack of positive role models: absence of caregivers who show emotional intelligence<br>            - Insecure attachment styles can impact trust and emotional understanding<br>        - Cognitive Factors<br>            - Mental health condition : stress, depression, autism<br>            - Limited social interaction : prevent development of broader perspective in life<br>        - External factors<br>            - Limited access to resources<br>                - Education, therapy<br>            - Gender stereotypes<br>                - Restricting oneself to gender roles can restrict emotional development<br>            - External pressures<br>                - E.g. rioting post Nahel M killing in France<br>                - E.g. Manipulation<br>                - E.g. Terrorism, extremism etc.<br><br>- - **Way forward**<br>        - “The only way to change someone’s mind is to connect with them from the heart.” <br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - EI is a tool for effective communication and peaceful coexistence with others.<br>        - EI is a tool for effective tool to win friends and influence people.<br><br>- - As Daniel Goleman says, emotional intelligence can be a valuable resource, However it should be supported by a strong moral compass and ethical reasoning. | - 1. **Attitude**<br><br>Content \| Structure \| Function                                                   | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Oxford dictionary defines attitude as 'A way of thinking or feeling about something'<br>        - Attitude is a person's learned and enduring tendencies to behave either favourably or unfavourably towards something.<br>        - The only disability in life is a bad attitude." - Scott Hamilton<br>        - Winston Churchill - 'Attitude is a little thing that make big difference'.<br><br>- - Belief VS Attitude<br>        - Belief is a conclusion regarding something. (cognitive)<br>        - Attitude includes cognitive, affinitive and behavioral component.<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 9.png>)<br><br>- - **Attitude formation**<br>        - Direct Personal Experience:<br>            - E.g. positive encounter with a friendly dog might create a positive attitude towards dogs in general.<br>        - Family and Social Influence<br>            - through implicit learning, shared values, and social norms.<br>        - Formal Education<br>            - by providing knowledge, critical thinking skills, and exposure to diverse perspectives.<br>        - Media and Information<br>            - by framing information, presenting stereotypes.<br><br>- - **Attitude for a civil servant**<br>        - Service Orientation:<br>            - Putting the needs of the public above personal gain or political pressure<br>        - Impartiality and fairness<br>            - Treating all citizens equally<br>        - Accountability and transparency<br>            - Taking responsibility of action; being open to public scrutiny.<br>        - Professionalism:<br>            - Having necessary knowledge, skills, and experience to fulfill duties<br>        - Integrity<br>            - Having highest ethical standards; avoiding conflicts of interest and corruption.<br>        - Problem-Solving attitude<br>            - Responding effectively to challenging circumstances<br>        - Empathy and compassion<br><br>- - **Positive attitude**<br>        - Refers to optimistic frame of mind<br>        - Positive and constructive thinking<br>        - Self confidence; personal resilience; sense of purpose<br>        - Growth mindset<br>        - motivation and energy<br>        - Mindfulness and stress management techniques<br>        - Critical thinking and problem-solving qualities<br>        - Necessary for innovation<br>        - Help managing adverse circumstances<br>        - Continuous learning<br>        - Leads to happiness, success, self esteem<br>            - E.g. Stephen Hawking, covid-19 management<br>        - External factors contributes to positive attitude in a person?<br>            - Supportive work environment<br>            - Sense of belonging and community<br>            - Strong relationships<br>            - Inspiring stories and role models<br>            - Knowledge and experience<br>            - For civil servants<br>                - Improve Problem-Solving<br>                - Genuine commitment to public service<br>                - Recognizing potential impact of actions<br>                - Continuously seeking learning opportunities<br><br>- - **Negative attitude - PAIRJBE**<br>        - Pessimism - consistently negative outlook<br>            - E.g. IAS in Bihar found scolding school teacher for wearing 'kurta'<br>        - Arrogance - Displaying an excessive sense of superiority (Apathy, Abuse of Public office)<br>            - E.g. IAS officer using public stadium for personal evening walks in Delhi<br>            - E.g. Pooja Khedkar forging documents in UPSC exam<br>        - Indifference - Showing lack of concern<br>            - E.g. DM in Tripura raiding marriage parties and misbehaving with guests.<br>        - Resistance to change - unwilling to embrace new ideas (Red Tapism)<br>            - E.g. resistance to lateral entry<br>            - E.g. abuse of official secrets act<br>        - Jealousy - resentful others' achievements<br>        - Blaming - attributing failures to external factors<br>            - Reward and punishment transfers<br>        - Escapism - not accepting responsibility<br>            - 21% bureaucrats were not responsive to social audits - Accountability Research Centre<br>        - Always expecting failure<br>        - Issue<br>            - Holds us back<br>            - Kills motivation<br>            - Lowers self esteem and confidence<br>            - Leads to failure<br>            - Increase anger, doubt, frustration, dwelling on problems.<br><br>- - Neutral attitude - it means being detached<br>        - Personality trait of being indifferent/ unemotional<br>        - Balanced (+ve)<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Democratic attitude\|Bureaucratic attitude (Weberian)\|<br>\|- - - Focus on public interest<br>        - inclusive, participative<br>        - Innovative<br>        - Prioritize outcomes over procedures\|- - - Strictly follow rules and process<br>        - Priority to order and efficiency<br>        - Hierarchy and chain of command oriented<br>        - Internal procedures over citizens needs<br>        - Status quoist, risk averse\|<br>\|- - - Merits<br>            - Responsive<br>            - Creativity and innovation<br>            - Public trust and legitimacy<br>            - Participation and ownership<br>        - Demerits<br>            - Slow and less efficient<br>            - Discretionary powers<br>            - Political influence and manipulation\|- - - Merits<br>            - Consistency and predictability in decision making<br>            - Minimizes errors and corruption<br>            - Reduce discretionary powers<br>        - Demerits<br>            - Inflexible to changing needs<br>            - Lack of public participation<br>            - Resistance to change<br>            - Apathy and indifference towards social cause\|<br><br>- - Balance between the two<br>        - Flexible guidelines and clear rules<br>        - exercise discretion within established framework<br>        - Participatory decision making<br>        - Robust accountability mechanisms to ensure fairness, transparency and ethical conduct.<br><br>- - Attitude Towards Weaker Sections<br>        - ‘Sarvodaya through Antyodaya’<br>    - Moral attitude<br><br>- - **How attitude can be changed ?**<br>        - Internal ways<br>            - Engage in critical thinking<br>            - Self-Awareness and Reflection:<br>                - Identify your own biases and prejudices<br>            - Learning and knowledge<br>                - Learning new things which challenges existing beliefs<br>        - External<br>            - Persuasion<br>            - Social influence<br>            - Mentorship and role modelling<br>            - Seek diverse perspectives and experience<br>            - Community engagement<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 10.png>)<br><br>- - **Prejudice**<br>        - Prejudice is negative preconception or attitude toward a individual or a group.<br>        - Example - **CERTS**<br>            - Racial prejudice against people of Northeast (Bezbaruah Committee)<br>            - social stigma around working women<br>                - **SPECS**<br>            - Racism :<br>                - Violence against blacks<br>            - Religion<br>                - Communalism<br>            - Ethnicity<br>            - Caste prejudice<br><br>E.g. practicing untouchability<br><br>- - How do remove prejudice?<br>        - Individual Level<br>            - Self reflection and awareness<br>            - Critical thinking and questioning<br>            - Education and exposure to diverse perspectives<br>        - Societal Level:<br>            - Increasing the inter group contact<br>                - Interfaith dialogue<br>            - Increasing interdependence<br>            - Removal of mistrust<br>                - Celebrating festivals together<br>            - Legal and institutional reforms: promoting equality and opportunity for all<br>                - E.g. Women Reservation Bill<br>        - Role of media : counteract negative stereotypes and provide positive role models.<br>            - E.g. PT Usha - president of IOA (breaking glass ceiling)<br>        - Challenge Stereotypes<br>            - E.g. Madam Curie - won two noble prize<br>            - E.g. Indra Noori - CEO of PepsiCo<br>        - Inclusivity<br>            - E.g. interfaith council, multiculturalism<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - Right attitude is needed for life of happiness and fulfillment. | ### Structure                                                                                               | - - **Components of Attitude**<br>        - CAB Model<br>            - Cognitive - beliefs, thoughts, and knowledge<br>            - Affection - feelings, emotions, and preferences<br>            - Behaviour - tendency to act in a particular way<br>                - Attitudes may not always directly translate into behavior due to situational constraints<br><br>- - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 11.png>)<br>    - Examples<br>        - Positive beliefs about environmental conservation (cognitive component) ----> feels strongly about protecting the environment (affective component) ----> more likely to engage in pro-environmental activities (behavioural component). | ### Function - KEVM                                                                                         | - - Knowledge function : help in understanding world around us and make judgements<br>    - Ego defensive function - protects self-esteem and help justify our actions<br>        - E.g. unable to understand language might lead to attitude about it's complexity<br>        - Issue - tends to blame external factors for negative outcomes<br>            - E.g. refusing to take responsibility for failing<br>    - Value-expressive function : attitude used for self expression<br>        - E.g. negative attitude towards violence<br>    - Motivation function : some attitude enables us to attain desired goals. | **_Its influence and relations with_**<br><br>### Thoughts \| Behavior                                      | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Thought are ideas or opinion produced by thinking.<br>        - Thinking is cognitive process which involves attention, perception, reasoning and judgement in mind.<br>        - _Mahatma Gandhi ones said, 'A man is but the product of his thoughts. What he thinks, he becomes'_<br>            - For example - Fear, curiosity, relief.<br>        - Behaviours are actions that can be observed.<br>        - Hatred - intense dislike or ill will<br><br>- - **Attitude is predictor of behavior**<br>        - But not always - it depends on strength of attitude<br>        - Examples<br>            - Positive attitude leads to affirmative actions<br>            - Negative attitude - abstaining action<br>            - Neutral attitude - balanced/ no action<br>            - Moral attitude - moral action<br><br>- - **Attitude factors predicting behaviours**<br>        - Attitude strength ( knowledge and experience leads to more strong attitudes)<br>        - Personal relevance<br><br>- - **Attitude's influence on Thoughts**<br>        - Attitudes shape the way individuals perceive events<br><br>E.g. A job seeker with positive attitude might see failure as learning experience<br><br>- - Decision-making:<br>        - E.g. health conscious may prioritize daily workouts<br>    - Problem-solving<br>        - An entrepreneur with growth mindset might view challenges as opportunities to learn<br><br>- - Specificity - Specific attitude we have to do something.<br>    - Congruence - state where one's thought, speech and action coincides<br><br>- - **Attitude's influence on Behaviour**<br>        - Motivation for doing specific action<br>            - Musicians may dedicate hours to practice<br>        - Social interaction<br>            - Friendly attitude leads to positive social behaviour<br><br>- - People tend to behave in ways that are consistent with their attitudes.<br>    - However, Attitudes do not always directly translate into behaviour because<br>        - Situational constraints<br>        - Social norms<br>        - Conflicting attitudes<br>    - Attitude-Behavior Feedback Loop<br>        - When individuals engage in behaviours that are consistent with their attitudes, it reinforces and strengthens those attitudes.<br>        - Individuals engage in behaviours that are inconsistent with their attitudes, it may lead to cognitive dissonance. Faithfulness<br>        - Truthfulness<br>        - Goodness<br>    - Role<br>        - Facilitative<br>            - E.g. altruism, social service, etc.<br>        - Prohibitive<br>            - E.g. | ### Political Attitude                                                                                      | - - Political attitude means individual's beliefs about political matters, public policy and social issues.<br><br>- - Key characteristic **PPPI**<br>        - Ideological Orientation :<br>            - E.g. Liberals, Socialists, Marxists etc.<br>        - Policy Preferences :<br>            - E.g. views on issues such as taxation, immigration and foreign policy.<br>            - Other issues like economy, employment, women, inequality, caste system<br>        - Political Participation:<br>            - such as voting, attending rallies, joining advocacy groups, or running for office. | ### Social Influence                                                                                        | - - Social influence refers to ways in which individual's attitudes, opinions, or behaviour changes in response to social environment.<br><br>- - Positive role<br>        - Learning and development : through interacting with others, observing their behaviour.<br>            - E.g. learning language, cultural practices in childhood<br>        - Motivation : motivated individuals can inspire us for self improvement<br>        - Helps in building trust and functioning effectively in groups<br>            - E.g. adhering to traffic rules ensures smooth functioning<br>        - Cultural transmission through tradition, practices and beliefs<br>            - Helps in preserving cultural identify and heritage<br><br>- - Negative role<br>        - Spread of misinformation<br>        - Prejudice<br>        - Stereotype<br>        - Manipulation<br>        - Social insecurity<br>            - Comparing oneself to others on social media<br><br>- - Forms of social influence<br>        - Conformity : desire for fit in<br>            - E.g. Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao<br>        - Compliance : acting according to expectations<br>            - Family expectations<br>                - E.g. Marriage, Career Choices, Lifestyles.<br>        - Internalization : adapting someone's beliefs as our own<br>        - Social learning : observing and imitating behaviour of others<br><br>- - Factors influencing social influence<br>        - Peer pressure<br>            - Healthy competition<br>            - Social media - YouTube, TikTok<br>        - Persuasion<br>            - E.g. Swachhata Pakhwada<br>            - E.g. ‘Selfie with Daughter’ campaign<br>            - E.g. LiFE campaign<br>        - Socialization<br>            - Caste system - lead to inter-caste marriage, restricted social interaction.<br>            - Cultural influence - Dressing (south - dhoti, north- kurta pajama), Marriage, Festivals - Diwali, Holi, Eid, Christmas, or Navratri.<br>        - Authority and Leadership<br>            - E.g. Standup initiative<br>            - E.g. in taking covid-19 vaccines<br>            - Community and religious leaders on religious beliefs and practices.<br>            - Political leaders influencing voting behaviours.<br><br>- - **Negative**<br>        - Hate speech<br>        - Radicalization - lone wolf attack<br>        - Mob Vigilantism, lynching, blasphemy, Honour killings<br><br>- - **Measures**<br>        - Cultivating critical thinking skills<br>        - Maintaining a healthy sense of self<br>        - surrounding oneself with positive influences<br>        - Consumer awareness<br>            - E.g. ‘Jago Grahak Jago’<br>        - Explicit disclosure<br>        - Strict actions against misleading.<br><br>- - Social influence is a double-edged sword. Understanding its complexities we can make informed choices and contribute to positive social environment | ### Persuasion                                                                                              | - - Persuasion is the art to influence someone's beliefs and opinions through communication<br>    - To convince, encourage or motivate someone<br>    - Positive intentions<br>    - E.g.<br><br>- - How persuasion is done?<br>        - Ethos (establishing credibility)<br>            - Doctor prescribing medicine<br>        - Pathos (Emotional Appeal)<br>            - NGOs evoking emotions for donation<br>        - Logos (Logical Appeal)<br>            - Mutual fund showing data to sell offerings<br>        - Repetition :<br>            - E.g. Viksit Bharat 2047 mission<br>        - Social Proof (people copy the actions of others): e.g. customer reviews on amazon<br>        - Scarcity : e.g. Flash sales and limited time deals<br>        - Reciprocity : offering test drives for car purchase<br><br>- - Positive Role of Persuasion<br>        - creating positive changes in society<br>            - Swachh Bharat Abhiyan<br>        - Motivate individuals to embrace new ideas<br>            - Do Boond Zindagi Ki (behavioral campaign)<br>        - Effective communication<br>        - Peaceful conflict resolution<br>        - Personal development and creativity<br>            - Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao<br><br>- - Negative role of persuasion<br>        - Manipulation<br>            - fear-mongering, spreading misinformation for personal benefit<br>        - For promoting harmful behaviors<br>            - smoking, gambling<br>        - Spreading prejudice : through persuasive communication.<br><br>E.g. communalism<br><br>- - Undermining critical thinking : lead to impulsive decisions<br>        - E.g. misleading advertising, political propaganda<br><br>- - **Effective persuasion - CGEE** ( छत्तीसगढ़ में extremism extreme है)<br>        - Understanding the audience<br>        - Establish credibility<br>            - Presenting logical and compelling argument<br>        - Finding a common ground<br>            - Sharing examples of others, open dialogue<br>        - Emotional appeal<br>            - Sharing stories, catchy slogans and music, humour<br>        - Providing evidence<br>            - Facts, data, research findings<br>        - Commitment and consistency<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 12.png>)<br>    - Manipulation<br>        - Wrong intent<br>        - Convincing for private or illicit means or ends.<br>            - E.g. manipulating people on religious lines<br>        - Impact<br>    - Persuasion should be used ethically and responsibly giving due consideration for it's potential consequences | - 1. **Aptitude and Foundational Values for Civil Service**                                                 | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Aptitude is person's inherent potential to develop certain skills, abilities, or knowledge.<br>        - It is concerned with the future potential.<br>        - **Ability** is much closer to intelligence. It is concerned with present.<br>        - Aptitude is neither completely innate, nor completely acquired<br>        - "Aptitude is your natural ability to do something well, but attitude is the determination to do it even better." - Lou Holtz<br><br>- - Aptitude and skills<br>        - Skills acquired and constantly upgraded<br>        - Training and learning<br>        - Aptitude is what is there, but could be nurture<br><br>- - **Body**<br>        - Two types of aptitude<br>            - Physical - physical characteristics to perform a task successfully<br>                - E.g. strength<br>            - Mental - mental qualities needed to perform a task successfully<br>                - E.g. banker dealing with numbers<br><br>- - **Civil servants must have three kinds of aptitude - EMI**<br>        - Intellectual<br>            - Think rationally, act purposely and deal effectively with his environment.<br>            - Means oriented aptitude<br>            - E.g. devising solutions like oxygen plants during COVID-19<br>        - Emotional<br>            - Effective conduct with colleagues, subordinate and public at large.<br>            - E.g. Divya Devarajan -<br>                - learn tribal language(Gondi) to make personal connection<br>        - Moral<br>            - Ensuring values like justice, empathy, fairness etc.<br>            - E.g. IAS officers adapting schools in Odisha<br><br>- - **Foundational Values**<br>        - **End oriented**<br>            - Concerned with the goals which civil servants aims to achieve while performing their duties<br>            - Covered by DPSP, FR's.<br>        - **Means oriented**<br>            - Concerned with ways in which civil servant behaves or acts while performing their duty<br>            - E.g. transparency efficiency.<br>        - **Constitutional values**<br>            - Sovereignty<br>            - Socialism<br>            - Secularism<br>            - Democracy<br>            - Republic<br>            - Justice<br>            - Equality<br>            - Fraternity<br>            - Rule of law<br>            - Integrity<br>            - Balance between freedom and self-restraint<br>        - **I-DOPE (** सिविल सर्वेंट कैसे होने चाहिए **- DOPE)**<br>            - Integrity<br>            - Impartiality<br>            - Dedication to public service<br>            - Objectivity and Rationality<br>            - Non-partisanship<br>            - Empathy and Compassion towards weaker sections<br>            - Tolerance<br>            - Anonymity<br>    - **Conclusion**<br>        - A strong civil servant demonstrates all of the above ethical traits in their day to day functioning.<br><br>- - 2nd ARC report on Ethics in Governance suggests, Public Service Values for all public servants should be clearly defined. | ### Integrity                                                                                               | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Consistently thinking and doing what is right all the time.<br><br>- - "Integrity is doing the right thing, even when no one is watching." - **C.S. Lewis**<br>    - Having consistency in thought, actions, and values.<br><br>- - Fundamental rule for maintaining civil servants integrity is to avoid situation that may give rise to conflict of interest.<br><br>- - Against integrity<br>        - Puja Khedkar<br>        - Abdul Khan - nuclear proliferation<br>        - Recent cases of doping in sports<br>        - Keshab Chandra Sen marrying of 13 years old daughter<br><br>- - Different types of integrity<br>        - Moral Integrity<br>            - Gandhi suspending NCM on incidence of violence in Chauri Chaura, 1922<br>        - Professional integrity ~ Probity<br>            - Whole team of Mission Shakti (nuclear program) kept the mission secret<br>        - Intellectual Integrity<br>            - Never lying on resume<br>            - Never cheating in exam<br>            - A doctor refusing to prescribe medication which he thinks unnecessary<br><br>- - Significance of integrity in human life - psychological/interpersonal/professional/governance/social<br>        - Building public trust<br>            - We trust a person who says and does the same thing<br>            - Mahatma Gandhi<br>        - Foster self respect and confidence<br>            - Nelson Mandela<br>        - Ethical professionalism<br>            - E.g. Ratan Tata<br>        - Do the right thing<br>            - Integrity guides us to follow ethics when faced with temptation or pressure<br>        - Personal growth<br>            - By always being accountable and responsible<br>        - Healthy interpersonal relationship<br>            - Develops honesty and fidelity<br>        - Better mental health<br>            - Living with integrity gives a sense of inner peace and confidence.<br>        - Prevent corruption and misuse of power<br>        - Good governance<br><br>- - Integrity without knowledge<br>        - Ineffective decisions due to lack of understanding<br>            - E.g. Hesitancy of farmers towards organic farming<br>        - Impractical choices based on principles alone<br>            - E.g. Premiership of Liz Truss<br>        - Risk of exploitation<br>            - E.g. unfair wages to women in unorganized sector<br>        - Rigidity<br>        - Greater harm<br>        - Contextual ethics : emergency situations<br>            - Need to follow moral intuition<br><br>- - Knowledge without integrity<br>        - Violation of ethics for personal gain<br>            - E.g. Ransomware attack<br>        - Harmful actions<br>            - E.g. Hate speech<br>        - Violation of trust<br>            - E.g. Abdul Khan - Nuclear proliferation<br><br>- - Cultivate both integrity and knowledge<br>        - Continuous learning<br>        - Critical thinking and fact-checking<br>        - Openness to feedback and adaptation<br><br>- - If you tell the truth, you don't have to remember anything.<br>    - Integrity is a value that empowers the human being<br>    - One of the tests of integrity is complete refusal to be compromised<br>    - “In looking for people to hire, you look for three qualities: integrity, intelligence and energy. And if they do not have the first, the other two will kill you.”<br>        - Intelligence and energy without integrity<br>            - [Knowledge without integrity](onenote:#GS4&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={44232157-14DC-244B-9A67-E7D81ED82C04}&object-id={01E8A7D6-BF16-C747-87C1-B2603AB25033}&3D&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br>            - Corruption :<br>                - Civil servants convicted for taking bribes<br>        - Integrity with intelligence and energy<br>            - Effective service delivery<br>                - DBT schemes of government<br>            - Protecting fundamental rights<br>                - Threat of data privacy in age of AI<br>            - Accountability and responsibility<br>                - Civil servants regularly conducting social audits<br>            - Sustainability<br>                - Railways planning to become carbon neutral by 2030 | ### Impartiality                                                                                            | - - Impartiality means to be unbiased and fair, and considering all perspectives in objective way.<br>    - Decisions based on objectivity, not on bias or prejudice<br>        - E.g. carrying out official work like procurement, recruitment, distribution of resources etc., on merit alone.<br><br>- - Significance<br>        - Fairness and justice<br>        - Preserving public trust<br>            - Impartiality of ECI is essential for free and fair election<br>        - Objectivity<br>            - Recruitment by UPSC based on merit alone<br>        - Upholding rule of law<br>            - Wrong to encounter criminal without trials<br>        - Prevent corruption<br>            - CBI and ED investigations free from bias<br>        - Effective policy formulation benefiting all stakeholders<br>            - PM Ayushman Bharat<br>        - Avoiding Conflicts of Interest<br>            - Civil servant Suo-moto disclosing conflict when allocating tenders if any stakeholder share personal relationship with him<br><br>- - Impartiality should always be coupled with application of conscience.<br>        - Situational sensitivity<br>            - Crisis management<br>            - Refugee crisis<br>        - Perceived lack of empathy<br>            - Weberian rule based mindset<br>            - PDS distribution to most vulnerable<br>        - Rigid decision-making causing miscarriage of justice<br><br>- - Political impartiality<br>        - Counter - favoring ruling disposition MLAs during contract awarding<br>    - Public impartiality<br>        - Counter - favoring one community over other<br><br>- - In conclusion, impartiality and non-partisanship are not just ideals but practical necessities for effective public service. | ### Non-partisanship                                                                                        | - - Non-partisanship is political neutrality<br>    - Civil servant doing his task without fear/favor of political party.<br>    - The values of the administrator will flow from the constitution not from the philosophy of any political party<br><br>- - **Significance**<br>        - Separation of power<br>            - Preventing politicization of bureaucracy<br>        - Professionalism<br>            - Appointment based on merit instead of political connection<br>        - Protect democratic mandate<br>            - Allocation of resource as per the parliamentary sanction<br>        - Peaceful conflict resolution<br>            - ECI recommendation to disqualify MP<br>        - Public service delivery<br>            - Anil Swarup dutifully implementing both RSBY and Ayushman Bharat<br>        - Continuity in administration<br>        - Public trust<br><br>- - Negative Examples<br>        - Civil servants joining political party<br>        - CAG - 2G Scam<br><br>- - Challenges<br>        - Politicized bureaucracy serves the narrow interest of political party in power - **committed bureaucracy**<br>            - E.g. - Nazi Germany<br><br>- - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 13.png>) | Neutrality                                                                                                  | - - **Neutrality** signify political impartiality of civil servants.<br>        - Behavioral component<br>    - Provisions under **Central Civil Services Conduct Rules, 1964 and the All India Services Conduct Rules 1968**<br>        - Public servants must not take part in politics<br>        - They must not give election fund/ assistance to any political party<br>        - Then must not tell their preference of vote to other people<br>        - They must not display any election symbols on his himself, vehicle or home.<br>        - They must not participate in rallies, and demonstrations etc., without government permission.<br><br>- - Types of neutrality<br>        - Passive neutrality<br>        - Active neutrality I believe rising intolerance towards minorities is wrong and violation of democratic spirit.<br>        - Introspection : reflecting on what are my core ethical values and principles. Indomitable will to never compromise them<br>            - E.g. I don't lie or indulge in irresponsible activities<br>        - Staying open to feedback : helps me to identify faults in my reasoning, and allows me to learn and improve.<br>        - Practicing humility in daily life : recognizing my role as someone to help others in achieving their goals<br>        - Environment stewardship : I have made Lifestyle for environment as integral part of my life.<br>            - E.g. I carry cloth bags and refuse to take polyethene bags.<br>        - Follow rules and laws<br>            - E.g. I wear helmet while riding bike and stop at traffic signal even if nobody is watching<br><br>- - Why ethics is important in public administration?<br>        - Maintaining public trust and legitimacy<br>        - Preventing corruption and abuse of power<br>        - Justice and Fairness<br>        - Upholding the rule of law and democracy<br>        - Setting an example for society<br>        - Protection of environment and wildlife<br>        - Progressive social change<br><br>- - Ethically right legally wrong<br>        - Bending rule for compassion : Blood transfusion to a pregnant women during natural disaster without following procedures<br>        - Whistleblowing :<br>        - Civil disobedience : peaceful protest against unjust laws.<br><br>- - Legally right ethically wrong<br>        - Intentional delay : governor using pocket veto on state bills.<br>        - Misuse of power : A police official entrusted to clear peaceful protesters use violent means without prior warning.<br>        - Freedom of speech : misuse of fundamental right to spread hate towards other community<br><br>- - “In doing a good thing, everything is permitted which is not prohibited expressly or by clear implication”. Examine the statement with suitable examples in the context of a public servant discharging his/her duties.<br>        - Issues with such discretion<br>            - Risk of misuse of power<br>            - Undermines Rule of Law<br>            - Long term harm<br>        - Advantages of discretion<br><br>- - In conclusion, while having good intention is essential, public servants should never operate outside the framework of established law and ethics.<br><br>- - **Public interest** refers to the collective well-being and good of all citizens within a society<br>        - Principles - IOSHOLA<br>        - Procedures<br>            - Transparency and accountability<br>            - Public participation<br>            - Management of conflict of interest<br>            - Efficient public service delivery<br>            - Professionalism<br><br>- - Ethics is essential foundation for effective and responsible public administration. | ### Accountability and Responsibility                                                                       | - - Accountability means being answerable for one's action and decisions to all stakeholders.<br>        - E.g. Lal Bahadur Shastri resigned after railway accident.<br>    - Includes<br>        - Answerability<br>            - To justify one's action<br>        - Enforcement<br>            - To take action in cases of omission<br>        - Grievance redressal<br>    - Responsibility - accountability to oneself based on ethical reasoning<br>        - When accountability turns inwards<br>        - Based on ethical reasoning<br>        - Taking ownership of one's actions and decisions.<br>    - Financial accountability<br>        <br>    - Institutions and mechanisms<br>        - External (to citizens)- RTI, Elections, civil society, Media, Citizen's Charters, Whistle Blowers<br>        - Internal (within government)- system of checks and balances<br>            - Parliament, judiciary, CIC, CVC, Lokpal, internal audits, POC Act, E-gov mechanism (Pragati, NeGP)<br>    - How to improve accountability<br>        - Need for citizen's charter<br>        - Devising standard operating procedures<br> | ### Philosophical Basis of governance                                                                       | - - The philosophical basis of governance means fundamental principles about how societies should be ruled and organized.<br><br>- - Virtue theory<br>        - for developing virtuous citizenry<br>        - Plato and Aristotle<br>    - Divine command theory -<br>        - Robert Filmer, St Augustine<br>    - Social Contract Theory :<br>        - For protecting inalienable rights of life, liberty, and property<br>        - Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and Rousseau<br>    - Utilitarianism :<br>        - Governments job is to maximize happiness and well-being for the greatest number of people.<br>        - Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill<br>    - Marxism -<br>        - Human Emancipation, Egalitarianism<br>    - Republicanism :<br>        - civic virtue, active citizenship, and public participation in governance. -Aristotle, Hannah Arendt, Jurgen Habermas<br>    - Justice Theories<br>        - For fair allocation of resources and opportunities<br>        - John Rawls | ## Ethical concerns and Dilemmas                                                                            | - - Ethical dilemma is a situation in which an individual has to make a choice between two moral principles, making it hard to determine what is the right thing to do.<br><br>- - Causes of ethical dilemmas<br>        - Conflict of values<br>        - Lack of clarity in policies, structures<br>        - Conflict of interest<br>        - Different perspectives<br>        - Changes in society - dynamism<br><br>- - Process of resolving ethical dilemma - **RIE-DL**<br>        - Recognize the Dilemma:<br>            - Identify the values and principles at stake<br>            - Consider the potential consequence of different action on all stakeholders<br>        - Gather Information<br>            - Collect relevant information like - applicable laws, policies, and code of ethics.<br>            - Research how similar dilemmas were addressed in the past<br>            - Seek input from affected stakeholders<br>        - Analyze Options<br>            - Consider all possible courses of action and their potential consequences.<br>            - Evaluate each option against your ethical principles, legal constraints<br>            - Apply ethical theories like deontology, utilitarian, to analyze the options<br>            - Consider what you can justify to others based on rational thinking<br>        - Implement the Decision<br>            - Take action to implement your chosen course of action effectively and ethically.<br>            - Ensure transparency and accountability throughout the process<br>        - Evaluate and Learn<br>            - Reflect on the decision and its consequences<br>            - Use the experience to learn for future situations and make suggestions to improve existing procedures<br><br>- - Role of innovativeness and creativity to resolve<br>        - Understanding the problem : through multiple perspective<br>            - P Narahari<br>        - Thinking outside the box:<br>            - considering unconventional approaches<br>                - Arif Sheikh - Chuppi Tod / community policing<br>            - borrowing from other sectors<br>                - JAM from Nandan Nilekani<br>            - utilizing technology in innovative ways<br>                - Asheesh Singh - Indore<br>        - Engaging with diverse stakeholders, experts and public at large<br>            - Divya Devarajan<br>        - Finding common ground<br>            - Joint forest management<br><br>- - Suppose the Government of India is thinking of constructing a dam in a mountain valley bound by forests and inhabited by ethnic communities. What rational policy should it resort to in dealing with unforeseen contingencies<br>        - Rational policy to consider<br>            - Comprehensive Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)<br>            - Public hearing and Informed Consent<br>            - Plan to protect culture and traditions<br>            - Resettlement, rehabilitation and fair compensation<br>            - Risk Mitigation and Contingency Planning:<br>                - Natural disaster response protocol (floods, earthquakes, etc.)<br>                - Environmental protection measures<br>            - Establish monitoring systems<br>            - Build local capacity<br>            - Open communication and transparency<br><br>- - Approach<br>        - Consequentialist (utilitarian)<br>        - Deontological<br>        - Rights<br>        - Contextualist<br>        - Justice and fairness<br>        - Virtue<br>        - Common good | ### Ethical issues in International Relations                                                               | - - **International relations**<br>        - International relations (IR) is a field that studies interactions and relationships between sovereign states and other international actors.<br><br>- - **Importance of ethics in international relations**<br>        - Promoting peace and security<br>            - Peaceful conflict resolution<br>                - India-Bangladesh border agreement<br>            - Non-proliferation<br>                - NPT<br>            - Cooperation during natural/man made disaster<br>                - 2004 Indian ocean tsunami relief<br>                - Vaccine Maitri<br>        - Protecting human rights<br>            - E.g. sanctions against Russia<br>        - Human security<br>            - Freedom, human rights<br>        - Rule of law<br>            - Following UNCLOS in South China sea<br>        - Environment protection<br>            - UNFCCC<br>            - Paris agreement, Montreal Protocol<br>        - Sovereignty and non-interference<br>            - E.g. Sri Lanka<br>        - Economic development<br>            - Non predatory lending<br>        - International institutions<br>            - UN, ICJ<br><br>- - Discuss the role of ethics and values in enhancing the following three major components of Comprehensive National Power(CNP)viz. human capital, soft power(culture and policies), and social harmony.<br>        - Role of Ethics and values in increasing CNP<br>            - Human capital<br>                - Responsibility, integrity<br><br>Development of skills and productive workforce<br><br>- - - - - Critical thinking<br><br>Innovation, creativity, problem solving skills<br><br>- - - - - Fairness, inclusivity<br><br>Promote merit, attract talent<br><br>- - - - Soft power<br><br>- - **Challenges and limitations**<br>        - Subjectivity : Ethics is subject to disagreement<br>            - Chinese don't follow rule based international order<br>        - Enforceability : Issue in enforcement<br>            - States have offensive military capabilities<br>        - National interest and principles - difficult choice<br>            - Buying Russian oil<br><br>- - Strength, peace and security are considered to be the pillars of international relations. UN Convention on Genocide in December **1948** - Genocide is **deliberate killing** of large number of people of particular ethnicity, religion, nation, etc.<br>        - Example<br>            - 1933-1945 Holocaust<br>            - 1994 - Rwanda<br>                - 800,000 Tutsis were killed by Hutu Militia<br>            - Cultural genocide<br>                - Uyghur Muslims, Xinjiang China<br>    - Organized crime<br>        - Arms trade<br>        - Tax heavens<br>    - WAR<br>        - Mankind must put an end to war before war puts an end to mankind. - John Kennedy<br>        - When going to war is justified<br>            - protecting innocent human life<br>            - against external aggression<br>            - Defending moral values<br><br>- - **Jus ad bellum (right to go to war) - LIC-AC-S**<br>        - Last resort : all other methods must tried first<br>        - Right intention : the intention of war is to right a wrong<br>        - Just cause : there must a good reason for going to war<br>        - Right authority : only public authorities are legitimate, terrorist organizations are not<br>        - Comparative justice - the suffering caused must be less then the suffering that exists<br>        - Probability of success : there is no point in fighting and wasting lives if you are not going to win<br><br>- - **Jus in bello (law of war) - MDP**<br>        - Discrimination - act of war should not be directed at civilians<br>            - E.g. Bucha massacre<br>        - Minimum force - death and destruction should be limited<br>            - E.g. strikes on civilian infrastructure<br>        - Proportionality - the force used must be proportional to the wrong endured and to the possible good that may come<br><br>- - **Jus post bello**<br>        - Concerns justice after a war, including peace treaties, reconstruction, war crimes trials, and war reparations.(RT)<br><br>- - **The four Geneva Conventions**<br>        - Convention 1 - Protect soldiers from execution without judgement. Right to proper medical treatment and care to wounded soldiers<br><br>•Protects wounded and sick soldiers on the battlefield.<br><br>•Requires humane treatment of the wounded without discrimination.<br><br>•Mandates respect for medical personnel and facilities, including the Red Cross emblem.<br><br>- - Convention 2 - Protection to shipwrecked soldiers, special protection to hospital ships.<br><br>•Extends protection to wounded, sick, and shipwrecked members of armed forces at sea.<br><br>•Similar protections as the First Convention, but applicable in maritime warfare.<br><br>- - Convention 3 - Defined prisoners of war and accorded them humane treatment<br>        - PoW must be protected against insult and public curiosity as well as act of violence or intimidation.<br><br>•Provides detailed rules on the treatment of POWs, ensuring they are treated humanely, given medical care, and not subjected to torture or degrading treatment.<br><br>- - Fourth Geneva Convention (1949):<br><br>•Protects civilians during times of war, particularly in occupied territories.<br><br>•Prohibits deportation, hostage-taking, and the targeting of civilians, among other protections.<br><br>- - War does not decide who is right but who is left.”<br>    - Injustice anywhere is threat to justice everywhere<br><br>- - Management of Global commons - Tragedy of commons [Garret Hardin]<br>        - **HAAO**<br>        - High seas<br>        - Atmosphere<br>        - Antarctica<br>        - Outer space<br>        - Ethical concerns - governance<br><br>- - Way forward<br>        - Different actions are required by different agents in different contexts to respond appropriately, humanely and ethically to the challenges of climate change.<br>        - Taking enlightened view of balance - Panchsheel<br>        - Commitment to multilateralism, plurality, environmentalism, fair representation of south at global stage.<br>        - Preventing erosion of pubic trust<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - International relations should become positive sum game benefiting all stakeholders.
