| ### Laws                                                                                                    | - - Laws are rule which are enacted with due process by a competent authority<br>    - Basic ethical standards that society expects everyone to follow<br><br>- - Enforceable punishments<br>        - E.g. POSH Act, 2013<br>        - POCSO Act, 2012<br>        - IPC Provisions<br>    - Purpose - promote common good and protect individual rights<br>    - Enacted by formal authority<br>    - Applicable to broader population<br>    - For specific action and situations<br><br>- - Laws: Speed limits, criminal codes, tax laws.<br><br>- - Matsya Nyaya<br>        - Law of jungle<br>        - Bigger fish eating smaller fish<br><br>- - How they provide ethical guidance<br>        - Setting boundaries of expected, permitted and prohibited actions<br>            - E.g. mandatory social audit under MGNREGA<br>        - Promote justice and fairness<br>        - Act as deterrence against misconduct<br>            - E.g. Suo moto disclosure of conflict of interest<br>            - E.g. murder<br>        - Adapt to evolving social values<br>            - Altruistic surrogacy<br>        - Help clarify the values to be used and procedure to be followed.<br><br>\|   \|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|---\|<br>\|SEF-SOC\|**Ethics**\|**Laws**\|<br>\|Source\|moral philosophy, personal beliefs, and societal values.\|legislative bodies\|<br>\|Enforcement\|Voluntarily enforced by conscience\|enforced by the state\|<br>\|Flexibility\|Evolve with individual and societal changes\|More rigid requires formal amendments\|<br>\|Scope\|Broader and subjective\|Narrower and uniform\|<br>\|Objective\|guide individuals toward virtuous living\|maintain public order, protect rights, and punish wrongdoing\|<br>\|Consequences of Violation\|social alienation or crisis of conscience\|Fines, imprisonment, punishment\|<br>\|- - - Laws can lead to ethical change<br>            - E.g. Abolishing slavery by law<br>            - E.g. Hindu Succession Act<br>            - Abolition of Capital Punishment:\|<br>\|Impacts where\|Ethics condition thoughts\|Laws conditions actions\|<br>\|Moral ambiguity\|What is unethical may not always | ### Rules                                                                                                   | - - Rules are a set of principles governing people.<br><br>- - **Rules and Laws**<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Laws\|Rules\|<br>\|Enacted by legislative body<br><br>E.g. parliament\|Can be set by individuals or organizations<br><br>E.g. \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Laws\|Rules\|<br>\|Reflect fundamental ethical principle<br><br>E.g. justice, fairness, human rights\|Reflect specific<br><br>E.g. impartiality, political | ### Conscience                                                                                              | - - Conscience is inner sense of right or wrong<br>    - Conscience is inner sense or faculty. It gives us sense of what is right or wrong.<br>        - E.g. Justice HR Khanna's dissenting judgement in ADM Jabalpur<br><br>- - Advantages of conscientious decision making<br>        - Questions unjust laws<br>            - Rosa Park defiance against racial segregation in Montgomery<br>        - Impose an obligation to be moral even in absence of laws<br>            - Ethical AI and Biotechnology<br>            - E.g. Edward Snowden - whistleblowing of espionage on civilians<br>        - Specific to individual<br>            - Provides moral guidance in ethical dilemmas which occurs in unique situations and circumstances<br>            - E.g. Doctor refusing to perform unnecessary surgery prescribed by hospital<br>        - Conscience can adapt and evolve alongside societal norms and personal growth<br>            - Laws can be outdated<br>            - E.g. Section 377 IPC<br>        - Not ethically correct to act on doubtful conscience<br>            - A doubtful law does not binds<br>            - E.g. leaking sensitive information by civil servant for transparency<br><br>- - Limitations<br>        - Subjectivity : May be certain, doubtful, probable<br>            - can lead to inconsistencies and potential harm<br>            - E.g. caste/religion based discrimination<br>        - Prone to manipulation<br>            - propaganda and social pressure can manipulate individual consciences<br>            - E.g. Hitler's propaganda<br>        - Conscience lacks external enforcement mechanisms<br>            - No sanctions for unconscientious acts<br>            - E.g. underpaying workers by corporates<br>        - Unequal application : education, reflection, and exposure to diverse perspectives makes person more conscientious<br>            - E.g. someone in corrupt environment may not see an issue in taking bribes<br><br>- - Crisis of conscience is a internal conflict which arises when individuals core moral principles clash with their obligation.<br>        - It's a struggle between what you know is right and what is convenient, tempting, or expected.<br>            - E.g. IPS officer monitoring peaceful protests, was ordered to take strict action.<br>    - Incidence from personal life<br>        - I was working on developing an application in my company. I discovered that the application has critical security flaws that may threaten the security of lakhs of users. My colleague insisted on finishing the project on the deadline regardless of the risk. This situation presents a crisis of conscience where I have to make a decision on releasing the application with security risk or raising the concern to higher-ups and refusing to release, which may cause a delay or even financial loss.<br><br>- - How I resolved this?<br>        - I raised the concern with my manager. He assured me not to worry of any retaliation and ensure that the security flaws are fixed before releasing.<br><br>- - **How does it manifest in public domain?**<br>        - For public servant<br>            - Compassion v/s rules<br>                - Helping citizens in distress bypassing rules<br>                - Crisis situation<br>            - Ethical v/s legal<br>                - Whistleblowing<br>            - Integrity v/s following orders<br>                - Verbal orders of senior<br>        - For institutions<br>            - Environment v/s development<br>            - Substantive equality v/s formal equality<br>                - Affirmative action?<br>            - National security v/s freedom of speech and privacy<br>            - Development v/s community rights<br><br>- - **How to resolve COC**<br>        - Recognize<br>        - Analyze<br>            - Self reflection and critical thinking<br>        - Seeking clarity : asking orders in writing<br>        - Consulting trusted people<br>            - Having diverse perspective helps in decision making<br>        - Prioritize values<br>            - Reflect to your core values and take decisions accordingly<br>        - Be prepared for consequences<br>            - Be responsible for decisions and face the consequence with integrity and courage.<br><br>- - **What acts as guiding values?**<br>        - Gandhi's Talisman<br>        - Emotional intelligence<br>        - Critical thinking<br>        - Moral reasoning<br>        - Having strong ethical foundation<br><br>- - Neither conscience nor laws and regulations are foolproof guides to ethical decision-making. Ultimately, the most reliable approach likely lies in a balanced combination of both. | ### Code of Ethics \|<br><br>Code of Conduct                                                                | - - Code of Ethics - is an **aspirational** document containing core ethical values, principles and ideals of the organization.<br>        - Values which behave like general principle to guide behaviour.<br><br>- - Code of Conduct - is a **directional** document containing specific practices and behaviour, that are followed or restricted under the organization.<br><br>- - _Purpose of Having Codes ?_<br>        - Minimum standard of behaviour required for all civil servants<br>        - Moral guidance in taking decisions<br>        - Professional standards in civil services<br>        - Sense of accountability, responsibility and tolerance.<br><br>- - _Characteristics of code_<br>        - Desirable<br>        - Feasible<br>        - Enforceable<br>        - Justiciable - Punishment for breach<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 15.png>)<br><br>- - **Codes of ethics for civil servants**<br>        - Personal responsibility<br>        - Compliance with law<br>        - Limitation on acceptance of gift, rewards.<br>        - Limitation on political activities<br>        - Confidentiality<br>        - Build public trust<br>        - Manage conflict of interest - professionally and personally<br>            - Public interest is supreme<br>            - Disclose any clash of interest<br>        - Financial prudence<br>        - Accountability to citizen's<br>        - Non abuse of official position<br><br>- - Issues<br>        - No Mention/framework of code of ethics in AIS(conduct) rule 1964<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Code of Ethics\|Code of Conduct\|<br>\|Aspirational document<br><br>Contains core ethical values and principles\|Directional document<br><br>Contains specific practices and behaviors\|<br>\|Broad context<br><br>Guide moral decision making\|Narrow context<br><br>For day-to-day behaviour\|<br>\|Not enforced<br><br>relies on persuasion and social influence\|Enforceable<br><br>Attract disciplinary measures for violations\|<br>\|Designed to promote ethics<br><br>Integrity, objectivity, rationality\|Designed to protect wrong<br><br>Corruption, giving/receiving inappropriate gifts\|<br>\|Abstract<br><br>Philosophical in nature\|Concrete<br><br>Contains specific prescription\|<br>\|Ex. Hippocratic oath for doctors<br><br>Ex. Corporate values\|Ex. Medical guidelines<br><br>Ex. Employee handbook\|<br><br>- - Public service code<br>        - Is a comprehensive set of guidelines for governing conduct and functioning of public services.<br>        - Key features ( 2nd ARC 10th Report)<br>            - Public service values : IOSHOLA<br>            - Clearly outlined code of ethics and conduct<br>            - Provisions for punishment for transgression<br>            - Preventive measures for malicious complaints against civil servants<br>        - Issues in implementation<br>            - Implementation Hurdles : Resistance from bureaucracy<br>            - Lack of political will<br>            - Monitoring mechanism : under limited capacity and human resources<br>            - Rigidity : can adversely impact situational decision making<br>                - E.g. crisis management<br>        - Full implementation of PSC is essential to address challenges of public sector.<br><br>- - Benefits of discipline<br>        - Orderly and smooth functioning<br>            - Because predictable environment<br>        - Accountability and performance<br>            - Non compliance may attract sanctions<br>        - Teamwork<br>            - Discipline establish trust and respect<br>        - Efficiency<br>            - Because of standardized procedures<br>    - Limitations of excessive discipline<br>        - Can impede creativity, risk-taking<br>        - Reduce morale and engagement<br>            - Employee feels like cog in a machine<br>        - Poor decision-making<br>            - Overreliance on orders can hinder independent thinking<br>        - Conflicts and resistance<br>            - Excessive control and micromanagement can breed resentment<br>    - Finding Balance<br>        - Outcome orientation<br>            - Allowing flexibility and encouraging ownership<br>        - Promote autonomy in decision making<br>        - Open communication<br>            - Encouraging employees to voice concerns and suggesting reforms<br><br>- - In conclusion, while discipline is a valuable tool, it needs to applied thoughtfully by finding right balance.<br><br>- - Both documents are essential for promoting a positive and responsible work | Conflict of interest                                                                                        | - - Conflict of interest - a situation in which a person is in a position to derive personal benefits from decisions made in official capacity.<br><br>- - Types<br>        - Financial conflict<br>            - E.g. Chanda Kochhar lending to Videocon<br>        - Non-financial conflict<br>        - Conflict of roles<br>            - Official duties<br>            - Private interests<br>            - Public interest<br>    - Ways it manifest in decision making<br>        - Awarding contracts<br>        - Policy decisions<br>        - Resource allocation<br>        - Conflicting responsibility<br>        - Conflict in values<br><br>- - Causes<br>        - Conflict in moral values<br>            - Evicting ST's from their land due to pressure from high authority<br>        - Family interest<br>            - Framing policies to benefit family business<br>        - Financial interest<br>            - Company offering financial benefits to lobby for a policy<br>        - Conflicting responsibility<br>            - Civil servant given additional charges with conflicting responsibility<br>            - E.g. mining and environment conservation portfolio<br>        - Outside pressure<br>            - From a political party<br>        - Conflicting organization<br>            - Civil servant being part of development work that has to clear trees, but also part of environmental NGO<br>        - Lack of awareness<br>            - Giving loans or contracts without knowing stakeholders<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Actual\|Potential\|<br>\|personal interest already impacted the professional duty\|Possibility of impacting\|<br>\|Ethical values are compromised\|Ethical values in position to get compromised\|<br>\|Requires immediate action<br><br>May involve disciplinary measures\|Requires mitigation strategies<br><br>E.g. recusal, disclosing, appointing neutral decision maker\|<br>\|Ex. | - 1. **Probity In Governance**                                                                              | - - **Introduction**<br>        - A government is good when it aims at well being of whole community, bad when it aim's at it's own good. -Aristotle<br><br>- - **Probity -** it is the quality of having strong moral principles and strictly following them. It is integrity, honesty and commitment to public good.<br><br>- - **Probity in governance** is procedural uprightness. It means following ethics in governance and allowing actions and decisions to withstand public scrutiny.<br><br>- - **Need of** probity in governance - REDCARPET<br>    - Principles of probity - IO-SHOLA<br><br>- - Difficulties in practicing probity in present times<br>        - Pressure to deliver [neoliberal paradigm]<br>        - Political fragmentation and polarization : making it difficult for public officials to act objectively and prioritize the common good over partisan interests.<br>        - Pressure groups : lobbying activities can influence decision making that benefits broader public good.<br>        - Social media : misinformation can cloud judgement making it harder to understand truth<br>        - Economic pressure : financial hardship, personal ambitions can tempt public officials to compromise their principles<br><br>- - **Significance**<br>        - Build trust in state institutions<br>            - E.g. ECI<br>        - Enhancing Credibility and Legitimacy<br>            - E.g. Social Audit mechanisms<br>        - Upholding public trust<br>            - E.g. RTI Act, 2005<br>        - Leads to good governance<br>            - E.g. TN Sheshan's in electoral reforms<br>        - Helps in checking abuse and misuse of power and discretion<br>            - E.g. Lokpal and Lokayukta Act of 2013 instills independent oversight over public officials<br>        - Leads to better service delivery<br>            - E.g. E Shreedharan commitment of time bound completion of Delhi Metro<br>        - Fair and equitable distribution of resources<br>        - Institutional integrity<br>        - Promoting social welfare<br>            - E.g.<br>        - Societal expectation<br>        - Develop confidence in investors<br><br>- - **Issue in India**<br>        - lack of will, lack of discipline<br>            - Gunnar Myrdal - 'soft society'<br><br>- - Development trap - FW Riggs<br>        - Failure to provide Capacity, differential treatment, equality<br><br>- - Development Decay - S Huntington<br>        - Political system becomes ineffective - corruption, lack of accountability, erosion of legitimacy.<br><br>- - **Measures**<br>        - Define Clear Ethical Standards<br>            - Code of ethics (2nd ARC)<br>        - Transparency and Disclosure<br>            - RTI, Citizen's charter<br>        - Robust Accountability Mechanism -<br>            - Internal Committees, CVC, CIC, Lokpal<br>        - E-government initiatives<br>            - PRAGATI, NeGP, **Probity portal, e-HRMS 2.0 portal**<br>        - Promoting Work culture of Integrity<br>        - Public participation<br>            - Social audit, civil society<br>        - Protecting whistleblowers<br>            - Forming safe channels for reporting corruption<br>        - Effectively enforce Code of conduct<br>            - Biometric monitoring, lateral entry<br><br>- - **Way forward**<br>        - NCRWC 'probity in governance<br>            - Focus on Legal, procedural aspects<br>        - TSR Subramanian case - Civil service board<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - Probity is vital ingredient for building a society where everyone can thrive.<br>        - We should strive towards a society where probity becomes a way of life, honesty becomes a routine expectation. | ### Concept of Public Service                                                                               | - - Aristotle states, "A political society exists for the sake of noble actions, not mere companionship. It embodies the theoretical concept of expanding public interest."<br><br>- - A public service is a service which is provided by the government to people living within its jurisdiction<br><br>- - Key aspects of public service include:<br>        - Commitment to the public interest<br>        - Provision of essential services<br>        - Service-oriented mindset<br>        - Collaboration and partnerships<br>        - Professionalism and competence | ### Work Culture                                                                                            | - - Work culture refers to the collective values that exist within an organization, influencing the overall work environment.<br><br>- - Significance of WC<br>        - Employee satisfaction<br>            - Retains talent<br>        - Productivity and performance<br>            - E.g. spurs to go extra mile<br>        - Build networks and team collaboration<br>            - Based on Mutual trust<br>        - Induce Innovation and Creativity<br>            - Because of freedom of expression<br>        - Conducive emotional environment at workplace<br>            - E.g. prevent anxiety, depression<br>        - Inclusivity and women's safety<br>            - Because of diversity and inclusivity<br>        - Sustainable financial performance<br>            - Maintain investor and shareholders confidence<br><br>- - Work from home<br>        - Positives<br>            - Retention<br>            - Bigger talent pool<br>            - Productivity<br>            - Telecommunication<br>        - Negatives<br>            - Communication gap<br>            - Anxiety<br>            - Mutual trust, connection and mutual purpose<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Coercion\|Undue influence\|<br>\|explicit threats or intimidation<br><br>E.g. threat of transfer\|is a form of manipulation that exploits trust<br><br>E.g. familial influence to leak sensitive information for personal gains\|<br>\|overt/explicit in nature\|subtle/implicit\|<br>\|Creates hostile and fear-driven work culture<br><br>- - Threatening to fire\|can undermine fair decision-making<br><br>- - E.g. luring for promotion\|<br>\|Can erode trust and damage morale\|can lead to biased practices, and conflicts of interest\|<br><br>- - Measures<br>        - Explicit core values<br>            - Code of ethics, code of conduct, citizen's charter<br>        - Improve transparency, accountability and feedback mechanisms<br>        - Internal Complaints Committee<br>        - Establishing system of checks | ### Quality of Service Delivery                                                                             | - - **Introduction**<br>        - "The quality of a nation's public service delivery reflects its commitment to the well-being and progress of its citizens"<br><br>- - [Significance](onenote:#GS4&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={44232157-14DC-244B-9A67-E7D81ED82C04}&object-id={8B547FD1-CBE7-D54F-9990-467B5EB42184}&A5&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br><br>- - **Issues in effective public service delivery**<br>        - Mismanagement : can delay crucial services, waste resources<br>        - Bureaucratic attitude : leads to slow decision-making<br>            - Avg. 59 months for land acquisition<br>        - Erosion of trust<br>            - Not prioritize their well-being of citizens erode public trust<br>        - Capacity constraints : lead to ineffective solutions<br>            - Overburdened public servants have limited capacity to deal with multitude of core issues.<br>        - Corruption :<br>        - Secrecy<br><br>- - **Government Initiative**<br>        - Lokpal<br>        - E-governance<br>            - National e-governance plan (NGeP)<br>            - Government e-marketplace (GeM)<br>        - PRAGATI Initiative<br><br>- - **How to increase quality of service delivery?**<br>        - Focus on citizens needs<br>            - Participatory planning and policy formulation - Kerala<br>        - E-governance<br>        - Establish independent regulatory mechanism<br>        - Encouraging reward and good work<br>        - Feedback Mechanism<br>            - DISHA - Gujarat for tribal areas<br>        - Social accountability<br>            - Community scorecard - Maharashtra, AP<br>        - Performance-based Incentives<br>        - Social audits<br>            - Ex - AP and Meghalaya<br><br>- - Balance between core issues and peripheral issues<br>        - Prioritization : identify core issues that are most significant<br>        - Data-driven decision-making : utilize modern tools for making informed decisions<br>        - Open communication : with stakeholders to understand their concerns and provide solution | ### Utilization of Public Funds                                                                             | - - "The true measure of a society's progress is how wisely and effectively it utilizes its public funds." - John F. Kennedy<br>    - [Significance](onenote:#GS4&section-id={DA2D6583-6393-3942-9C6F-2F119C30EFDD}&page-id={44232157-14DC-244B-9A67-E7D81ED82C04}&object-id={8B547FD1-CBE7-D54F-9990-467B5EB42184}&A5&base-path=https://d.docs.live.net/9b24b3fb5359b984/Documents/My%20Notebook/short%20notes.one)<br><br>- - **Reasons for underutilization**<br>        - Lengthy approval processes, red tape : due to excessive legal and compliance burden<br>        - Inadequate planning<br>        - Lack of Capacity<br><br>- - Reasons for misutilization<br>        - Political Interference<br>        - Lack of accountability<br>        - Corruption and other form of financial misconducts<br>        - Weak Monitoring and Oversight<br>        - Lack of Public Awareness and Participation<br>    - Implication<br>        - Missed Development Opportunities :<br>            - For development goals like poverty reduction, healthcare, infrastructure development<br>        - Loss of Public Trust and Confidence<br>        - Limits economic growth - create vicious cycle of financial obligations<br>            - Debt/GDP - 83%<br><br>- - **Way forward**<br>        - Strengthening Financial Management system<br>            - CAG<br>            - Public fund management system (PFMS)<br>            - DBT, FRBM use of JAM<br>        - Promote citizen engagement<br>            - Social audits<br>        - Open government initiatives<br>            - E-governance<br>            - E2E E-procurement and single window administrative mechanisms<br>    - **Conclusion**<br>        - "Utilizing public funds responsibly is a commitment to ensuring that every rupee spent delivers maximum value and benefits to the people" | ### Challenges of Corruption                                                                                | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Word bank - “Corruption is the abuse of public funds or office for private or political gains.”<br>        - According to 2nd ARC 4th Report - Corruption is a manifestation of the failure of the ethics and value system in society.<br>        <br>        - According to Transparency International, India was 85 among 180 countries in the corruption perception index 2022.<br><br>- - I sincerely believe in the words of Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam. Corruption which is misuse of public office or position for personal gain is manifestation of erosion of ethics. For a society to become corruption free ethical development is of paramount importance.<br><br>- - **Causes of corruption**<br>        - Institutional<br>            - Lack of Transparency and accountability<br>                - Coal and Fodder Scam<br>            - Weak law enforcement : does not create legal deterrence<br>                - Gunnar Myrdal - calling India as 'Soft State'<br>            - Over centralisation of administrative system<br>                - Legacy of colonial rule<br>            - Unregulated electoral funding<br>                - electoral bonds provisions without public disclosure<br>        - Individual<br>            - Greed and Self-Interest<br>                - The Panama Papers leak exposed tax evasions<br>            - Erosion of ethical values<br>            - Corruption to bypass bureaucratic hurdles and obtain essential resources.<br>        - Societal acceptance : considers corruption as way of doing things<br>            - E.g. bribing RTO officials to expedite process is considered necessary<br>        - Systemic and Structural Issues:<br>            - weak institutions, inadequate legal frameworks, and poor enforcement of laws.<br><br>- - **Impact**<br>        - Erosion of Public Trust<br>            - Undermine legitimacy of government<br>            - Weaken democratic processes<br>        - Impaired public service delivery<br>            - Health, education, infrastructure development<br>        - Criminalization of politics<br>            - E.g. 43% criminal records; 29% serious charges - PRS Research<br>            - Vohra committee report highlight P-B-C nexus<br>        - Environment degradation<br>            - illegal exploitation of natural resources, unauthorized construction<br>        - Economic inequality<br>            - E.g. 10% have 80% wealth - Oxfam<br>        - Discourage Investment<br>            - E.g. 85/180 in corruption perception index<br>        - Undermine fair competition<br>            - E.g. monopolization, license raj<br>        - Loss of morale and motivation<br>            - Discourage honest public servants<br><br>- - **Two types**<br>        - small level - people are forced to pay for the job otherwise entitled - plays bigger role in perception formation of corrupt country.<br>            - E.g. bribe taken by police in passport verification<br>        - high level - where affluent and powerful people get substantial gain as an act of corruption<br>            - E.g. 2G Scam<br><br>- - **Government measures**<br>        - RTI Act, **2005**<br>            - Issue : huge backlog, delay in reply, limited Suo-moto disclosure<br>            - Solutions : adherence to time limit; digitization of information<br>        - Prevention of corruption act, **1988**<br>            - Issue : huge backlog of cases in CAT<br>            - Solution : time bound clearance of cases; efficient enforcement<br>        - Lokpal Act, **2013**<br>            - Issue - appointment, functioning and capacity<br>            - Solution - reducing dependence for funds, functions and functionaries<br>        - Code of conduct<br>            - Issue - poor enforcement mechanisms<br>            - Solution - monitoring and disciplinary action for transgression<br>        - Active Media<br>            - Issue : lack of investigative journalism; lack of protection<br>            - Solution : freedom of press; measures against retaliation by government<br><br>- - Benami transactions prohibition amendment act, 2016<br>    - Citizen charter, Social Audit<br>    - Open governance initiative - PAHAL, DBT, PRAGATI Portal<br><br>- - **Way Forward**<br>        - Value based education<br>            - Ramamurthy committee - emphasize moral education in schools<br>        - Transparency and accountability<br>            - Lokpal, Social Audits, Citizens Charter<br>        - Strengthening POA Act, 1988<br>            - 2nd ARC suggests to include<br>                - Abuse of authority<br>                - Obstruction of justice<br>        - E-governance<br>            - E.g. - E-Auctions, DBT, Cashless transaction etc.<br>        - Whistle blower's protection<br>            - Ensuring confidentiality<br>            - Cover corporate whistleblowers<br>        - Time bound grievance redressal mechanism<br>            - E.g. RTI Act<br>        - Administrative reforms<br>            - In training, posting, transfers.<br>        - International cooperation to fight transnational corruption<br>            - United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC)<br>            - E.g. M-Pesa in African Countries<br>        - Empowering CBI<br>            - granting greater autonomy, resources, and investigative powers<br>        - Regulatory frameworks<br>            - Code of ethics and code of conduct<br>        - Administrative decentralization with proper monitoring checks and balances<br>        - Work culture of Integrity<br>        - Ethical and spiritual training sessions<br>        - Primary socialisation<br>            - Teaching ethical values in parenting<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - By addressing the causes and implementing solutions, we can move towards a society where ethical conduct prevails.<br>        - Corruption thrives in the shadows of secrecy. Shedding light on it is our collective responsibility | Whistle blowing                                                                                             | - - **Introduction**<br>        - Whistleblowing means exposes wrongdoing or corruption within a organisation or system.<br><br>- - Examples<br>        - Satyendra Dubey, an IES officer<br>            - exposed corruption and illegal activities in NH2 construction<br>            - tragically lost his life<br>        - Manjunath Shanmugam<br>            - exposed the large-scale adulteration of petrol<br>            - murdered in 2005 by the petrol pump owner<br>        - Edward Snowden<br>            - Exposed NSA collection of personal data of citizens<br>            - Led to termination of program under USA Freedom Act<br><br>- - **Challenges for whistle-blowers**<br>        - Lack of Protections against retaliation<br>            - Face consequences like job loss, demotion, or harassment<br>        - Lack of legal protection<br>            - Deters whistleblowers to expose wrongdoings<br>        - Limited Anonymity<br>            - Lead to social stigma<br>        - Reputational Damage<br>            - character assassination, marginalization by co-workers<br>        - Emotional and Psychological Impact - mental health, anxiety, and trauma.<br><br>- - **Measures**<br>        - Whistleblower protection laws<br>            - Whistleblower Protection Act, 2014<br>        - Confidential Reporting Channels<br>            - E.g. Reform Lokpal<br>        - Public appreciation<br>            - Crusade against corruption awards<br>        - Independent Oversight and Investigation<br>            - E.g. CVC, CBI<br>        - International Collaboration<br>            - E.g. MNC misconduct<br>        - Promoting conducive work environment<br>            - E-office<br>        - Dedication to public service<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - **Neeraj Dutta Case, 2022** | ### Corporate Governance                                                                                    | - - **Corporate governance** refers to the system of **rules, practices, and processes** by which companies are directed and controlled.<br><br>- - "Good corporate governance is about leadership, integrity, and responsibility, all working together for the benefit of stakeholders." - Warren Buffett<br>        - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 16.png>)<br>    - Ethical cooperate governance<br>        - Cooperate social responsibility<br>            - ITC is operating around 2500 learning centers.<br>        - Adopting Fair market practices<br>            - Refraining from anti competitive activities<br>            - Unilever’s “Sustainable Living Plan”<br>        - Addressing environmental concern<br>            - Railways - carbon neutral by 2030<br>        - Strict adherence to laws and regulation<br>            - Code of conduct<br>        - Respecting diversity and promoting inclusivity<br>            - TATA's plan for LGBT+ inclusion in workforce<br><br>- - Efficient cooperate governance<br>        - Competent leaders and efficient teams<br>            - Narayan Murthy - Infosys<br>        - Risk management<br>            - HDFC Bank risk management framework<br>        - Innovation and technology<br>            - Reliance Jio in 4G rollout<br>        - Efficient resource utilisation<br>            - Apple - using recycled aluminium<br><br>- - **Issues**<br>        - **Social**<br>            - Discrimination<br>                - 5% women CEO's in India(Deloitte)<br>            - Sexism in workplace<br>            - False and misleading claims<br>                - Volkswagen’s emission scandal<br>        - **Governance**<br>            - Nepotism and favoritism<br>                - E.g. Satyam and Sahara scandal<br>            - Unfair market practices<br>                - E.g. Sun Pharma Insider Trading Case<br>            - Poor risk management<br>                - E.g. Nirav Modi case - PNB<br>            - Lack of internal audit, statutory audit<br>                - E.g. Chanda Kochhar - ICICI<br>            - Anti competitive practices : predatory pricing<br>                - E.g. e-commerce like Amazon, Flipkart<br>        - Environment pollution<br>            - E.g. mining and thermal power<br><br>- - **Measures**<br>        - Stakeholder participation - Ownership and control to shareholders<br>        - Ethical leadership<br>            - Independent BOD<br>        - Inclusivity<br>            - E.g. Norway mandated 40% board representation to other genders<br>        - Checks and balances<br>            - To prevent misuse and abuse of powers and information<br>        - Grievance redressal mechanism<br>        - Compassionate capitalism<br>            - Narayan Murthy<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - Good cooperate governance can ensure sustainable growth which entails planet, people and profit.<br>            - ![GS4](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/GS4 17.png>) | Corporate Social Responsibility                                                                             | Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) refers to the ethical obligation of companies to contribute to societal welfare beyond their profit motives.<br><br>- - "CSR is not a mere gesture, but a way of doing business responsibly and sustainably." -Narayana Murthy<br><br>- - **Mandate**<br>        - The CSR concept in India is governed by **Section 135** of the **Companies Act, 2013.**<br>            - mandates companies with net profit greater than 5 crore to contribute 2% average profit for last 3 years.<br>            - Or, If a company’s net worth is Rs. 500 crore<br>            - Or, If Companies with an annual turnover of Rs. 1000 crore <br><br>- - **Cooperate ethics**<br>        - Gandhi's Trusteeship Model<br>        - Economic Survey - Ethical wealth creation<br><br>- - **Example**<br>        - Negative<br>            - Bhopal Gas Tragedy - Union Carbide<br>            - Large scale deforestation for production of Palm oil.<br>            - Toxic cough syrup allegedly killed 70 children's in Gambia<br>        - Positive<br>            - TATA - Compassionate capitalism<br>            - Patent pooling<br>            - Taj employees evacuating hostages during 26/11<br>            - Village transformation mission Maharashtra - Deutsche Bank, Tata Trust, HUL<br>            - Apple's commitment to be carbon neutral by 2030<br>            - Mahindra’s “Rise for Good” initiative<br>            - Unilever’s “Project Shakti”<br><br>- - In contemporary world, corporate sector’s contribution in generating wealth and employment is increasing. In doing so, they are bringing in unprecedented onslaught on the climate, environmental sustainability and living conditions of human beings. In this background, do you Responsibility (CSR) is efficient and sufficient enough to fulfill the social roles and responsibilities needed in the corporate work mandated? Critically examine.<br>        - Effectiveness of CSR<br>            - Positive Impact on communities<br>            - Enhance companies reputation<br>            - Employee engagement<br>        - Limitations and criticism<br><br>- - **Positive role of CSR**<br><br>- - **Benefits**<br>        - Makes companies more profitable<br>        - Enhanced Brand Image<br>            - Tata Group high reputation<br>        - Customer Loyalty and Retention<br>        - Employee Engagement and Productivity<br>            - Positive work culture<br>        - Makes them sustainable<br>        - Resilience in long term<br>        - Reduce the intergenerational inequality<br>        - Promote inclusive growth<br>        - Build social capital<br>            - E.g. Tata Group<br>        - Reduce the carbon footprint and capacity building for sustainable long term business.<br>        - Short term pain on profits but fruitful dividends for years to come.<br><br>- - **Issues**<br>        - Skewed expense : 44% towards education and only 6% towards poverty and hunger<br>        - Geographical Bias : Maharashtra and Karnataka almost account for 60% of CSR funds.<br>        - Greenwashing CSR activities<br>            - E.g. H&M's environment scorecard<br>        - Sportswashing<br>            - E.g. FIFA world cup 2022, Qatar<br><br>- - Short term and ad-hoc plans<br>    - Lack of accountability<br>    - Corporate - NGO nexus<br><br>- - **Way forward**<br>        - Bottom up approach -<br>        - Due diligence, disclosure norms<br>        - Social impact assessment<br>        - CSR -> CSV (Creating social value)<br>        - Uday Kotak Committee<br><br>- - **Conclusion**<br>        - Following recommendations of Narayan Murthy Committee, CSR can pave way for compassionate capitalism.<br>        - As Henry David Thoreau said - "Goodness is the only investment that never fails".
